If you can keep scrolling, it‚Äôs a problem.The wave of layoffs across the U.S. isn‚Äôt just their problem‚Äîit‚Äôs our problem. Every day, talented professionals wake up to uncertainty, not knowing how they‚Äôll pay their bills, support their families, or take their next step.I make sure to post, comment, and share opportunities because I am blessed to be gainfully employed‚Äîand I know how quickly circumstances can change. It takes only a few moments to be kind. A few moments to reshare a job post and give someone more visibility. A few moments to acknowledge someone‚Äôs struggle and remind them they‚Äôre not alone.If you‚Äôve ever needed a door opened, a referral, or just a little encouragement‚Äîpay it forward. Let‚Äôs show up for each other. üíôhashtag#JobSearch hashtag#Layoffs hashtag#Support hashtag#Networking hashtag#KindnessMatters

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. OPM Workforce Reshaping Handbookhttps://lnkd.in/g-6whAjN

TEXAS RESIDENTS - Please REPOST and take five minutes for an important follow up to my previous message regarding how you can help increase pay for Direct Service Providers working with, among others, children and adults with IDD (intellectual and developmental disabilities): The House subcommittee¬†is meeting Tuesday and Wednesday OF THIS¬†WEEK to consider testimony about the¬†need for increased wages for our direct care staff. You can provide online support through the legislative portal at the following link: https://lnkd.in/gn-nswsZSHOULD YOU CHOOSE TO SUBMIT YOUR SUPPORT, YOUR COMMENTS MUST BE SUBMITTED BY WEDNESDAY FEB. 26th.INSTRUCTIONS: After clicking the link above, you will first have to verify you are a Texas resident and fill in your name, address and phone number. Next, scroll to the section labeled "Appropriations - S/C on Article II February 26, 2025 - 8:00 AM [E1.030]" and then to the subtitle labeled "Article II Special Provisions".  Click SELECT.  Then you can enter your message.  If you choose, a sample message you can cut and paste is below.  After that click submit.  Thank you in advance for taking the time to help!!SAMPLE MESSAGE: The State Supported Living Centers and the State Hospitals experienced severe manpower¬†shortages and turnover. On January 24, 2023 the Texas Health & Human Service Commission¬†announced an increase in Direct Support Professionals (DSP) starting wages to $17.50 per hour as authorized by the 88th¬†Legislature in Article II, Rider 95.¬†In its August 2024 Report required by Rider 95, Health Human Services reported to the¬†Legislature that as a result of the compensation change, filled positions have increased¬†dramatically from 15,460 in February 2022 to 18,331 in April 2024 and turnover has declined¬†from 40.70% to 25.84% in the same timeframe. DSP Filled Positions have increased from 3,964¬†in September 2022 to 5,006 in May 2024, an increase of 26.30%¬†Private Provider DSP‚Äôs have the same task responsibilities as the SSLC and SH DSP‚Äôs. Funding¬†DSP pay at the same level will increase filled positions, reduce turnover, and, MOST¬†IMPORTANTLY, dramatically improve quality of care and client outcomes.¬†I encourage you to provide for a starting wage of $17.50 per hour to properly compensate¬†those who care for the Special Needs Population and restore the unfilled positions in our DSP¬†Workforce. It will not only improve the quality of care but have a positive economic impact on¬†our DSPs and our State Economy.

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.



‚Ä¶more

üîé Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles üöÄIn 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments üìù as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud roles‚Äîpositions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:üìå Does this reflect the real-world work environment?üìå Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?üìå Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?üîç Evidence & Trends:‚úÖ AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.‚úÖ Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.‚úÖ Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineering‚Äînot just coding fluency.‚ö†Ô∏è The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that don‚Äôt measure real-world capabilities.---üåç The Perfect Hiring Process ‚Äì If We Lived in a Perfect Worldüîπ üìû Intro Chat (30 min) ‚Äì A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just ‚Äútell me about yourself.‚Äùüîπ üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) ‚Äì A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.üîπ ‚ö° Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) ‚Äì A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!üîπ ü§ù Team Fit & Culture (30 min) ‚Äì A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.üîπ üöÄ Decision in <1 Week ‚Äì Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---üõ†Ô∏è It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? Let's discuss! üëáhashtag#DevOps hashtag#SRE hashtag#CloudEngineering hashtag#AIinTech hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Observability hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#TechRecruiting hashtag#Infrastructure hashtag#CareerGrowth

When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

üîé Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles üöÄIn 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments üìù as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud roles‚Äîpositions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:üìå Does this reflect the real-world work environment?üìå Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?üìå Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?üîç Evidence & Trends:‚úÖ AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.‚úÖ Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.‚úÖ Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineering‚Äînot just coding fluency.‚ö†Ô∏è The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that don‚Äôt measure real-world capabilities.---üåç The Perfect Hiring Process ‚Äì If We Lived in a Perfect Worldüîπ üìû Intro Chat (30 min) ‚Äì A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just ‚Äútell me about yourself.‚Äùüîπ üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) ‚Äì A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.üîπ ‚ö° Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) ‚Äì A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!üîπ ü§ù Team Fit & Culture (30 min) ‚Äì A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.üîπ üöÄ Decision in <1 Week ‚Äì Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---üõ†Ô∏è It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? Post Content:
If you can keep scrolling, it‚Äôs a problem.The wave of layoffs across the U.S. isn‚Äôt just their problem‚Äîit‚Äôs our problem. Every day, talented professionals wake up to uncertainty, not knowing how they‚Äôll pay their bills, support their families, or take their next step.I make sure to post, comment, and share opportunities because I am blessed to be gainfully employed‚Äîand I know how quickly circumstances can change. Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

üîé Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles üöÄIn 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments üìù as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud roles‚Äîpositions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:üìå Does this reflect the real-world work environment?üìå Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?üìå Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?üîç Evidence & Trends:‚úÖ AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.‚úÖ Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.‚úÖ Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineering‚Äînot just coding fluency.‚ö†Ô∏è The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that don‚Äôt measure real-world capabilities.---üåç The Perfect Hiring Process ‚Äì If We Lived in a Perfect Worldüîπ üìû Intro Chat (30 min) ‚Äì A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just ‚Äútell me about yourself.‚Äùüîπ üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) ‚Äì A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.üîπ ‚ö° Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) ‚Äì A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!üîπ ü§ù Team Fit & Culture (30 min) ‚Äì A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.üîπ üöÄ Decision in <1 Week ‚Äì Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---üõ†Ô∏è It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? üè¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ü§îIn the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stack‚Äîeveryone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Let‚Äôs break it down:üìå üöÄ Google‚Äôs Influence on Startups:üîπ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Google‚Äîeven if they don‚Äôt actually need that complexity.üîπ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Google‚Äôs work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.üîπ Hiring & Evaluation: Google‚Äôs System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.üîπ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesn‚Äôt guarantee success.üìå ‚öñÔ∏è When Does Copying Google Make Sense?‚úÖ If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.‚úÖ If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.‚úÖ If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.üìå ‚õî When Is It a Mistake?‚ùå If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.‚ùå If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.‚ùå If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because they‚Äôre "the industry standard."üîπ üí° The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didn‚Äôt come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processes‚Äîit came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?üí¨ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Share your thoughts! üëáhashtag#GoogleEffect hashtag#Startups hashtag#TechCulture hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Entrepreneurship üöÄ

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.



‚Ä¶more

üîé Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles üöÄIn 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments üìù as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud roles‚Äîpositions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:üìå Does this reflect the real-world work environment?üìå Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?üìå Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?üîç Evidence & Trends:‚úÖ AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.‚úÖ Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.‚úÖ Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineering‚Äînot just coding fluency.‚ö†Ô∏è The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that don‚Äôt measure real-world capabilities.---üåç The Perfect Hiring Process ‚Äì If We Lived in a Perfect Worldüîπ üìû Intro Chat (30 min) ‚Äì A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just ‚Äútell me about yourself.‚Äùüîπ üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) ‚Äì A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.üîπ ‚ö° Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) ‚Äì A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!üîπ ü§ù Team Fit & Culture (30 min) ‚Äì A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.üîπ üöÄ Decision in <1 Week ‚Äì Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---üõ†Ô∏è It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? üè¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ü§îIn the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stack‚Äîeveryone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Let‚Äôs break it down:üìå üöÄ Google‚Äôs Influence on Startups:üîπ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Google‚Äîeven if they don‚Äôt actually need that complexity.üîπ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Google‚Äôs work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.üîπ Hiring & Evaluation: Google‚Äôs System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.üîπ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesn‚Äôt guarantee success.üìå ‚öñÔ∏è When Does Copying Google Make Sense?‚úÖ If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.‚úÖ If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.‚úÖ If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.üìå ‚õî When Is It a Mistake?‚ùå If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.‚ùå If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.‚ùå If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because they‚Äôre "the industry standard."üîπ üí° The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didn‚Äôt come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processes‚Äîit came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?üí¨ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Share your thoughts! üëáhashtag#GoogleEffect hashtag#Startups hashtag#TechCulture hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Entrepreneurship üöÄ

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. OPM Workforce Reshaping Handbookhttps://lnkd.in/g-6whAjN

DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

üîé Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles üöÄIn 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments üìù as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud roles‚Äîpositions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:üìå Does this reflect the real-world work environment?üìå Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?üìå Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?üîç Evidence & Trends:‚úÖ AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.‚úÖ Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.‚úÖ Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineering‚Äînot just coding fluency.‚ö†Ô∏è The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that don‚Äôt measure real-world capabilities.---üåç The Perfect Hiring Process ‚Äì If We Lived in a Perfect Worldüîπ üìû Intro Chat (30 min) ‚Äì A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just ‚Äútell me about yourself.‚Äùüîπ üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) ‚Äì A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.üîπ ‚ö° Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) ‚Äì A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!üîπ ü§ù Team Fit & Culture (30 min) ‚Äì A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.üîπ üöÄ Decision in <1 Week ‚Äì Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---üõ†Ô∏è It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? üè¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ü§îIn the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stack‚Äîeveryone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Let‚Äôs break it down:üìå üöÄ Google‚Äôs Influence on Startups:üîπ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Google‚Äîeven if they don‚Äôt actually need that complexity.üîπ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Google‚Äôs work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.üîπ Hiring & Evaluation: Google‚Äôs System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.üîπ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesn‚Äôt guarantee success.üìå ‚öñÔ∏è When Does Copying Google Make Sense?‚úÖ If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.‚úÖ If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.‚úÖ If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.üìå ‚õî When Is It a Mistake?‚ùå If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.‚ùå If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.‚ùå If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because they‚Äôre "the industry standard."üîπ üí° The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didn‚Äôt come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processes‚Äîit came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?üí¨ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Share your thoughts! üëáhashtag#GoogleEffect hashtag#Startups hashtag#TechCulture hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Entrepreneurship üöÄ

Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noise‚Äîsaving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Here‚Äôs how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :‚Ä¢¬†Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.‚Ä¢¬†You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.‚Ä¢¬†Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrong‚Ä¢¬†~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. ‚Ä¢¬†Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.‚Ä¢¬†Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deploy‚Ä¢¬†Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. You can rollback patches as they are fully deployed builds.https://lnkd.in/gEA647dB

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. OPM Workforce Reshaping Handbookhttps://lnkd.in/g-6whAjN

DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

üîé Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles üöÄIn 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments üìù as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud roles‚Äîpositions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:üìå Does this reflect the real-world work environment?üìå Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?üìå Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?üîç Evidence & Trends:‚úÖ AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.‚úÖ Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.‚úÖ Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineering‚Äînot just coding fluency.‚ö†Ô∏è The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that don‚Äôt measure real-world capabilities.---üåç The Perfect Hiring Process ‚Äì If We Lived in a Perfect Worldüîπ üìû Intro Chat (30 min) ‚Äì A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just ‚Äútell me about yourself.‚Äùüîπ üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) ‚Äì A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.üîπ ‚ö° Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) ‚Äì A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!üîπ ü§ù Team Fit & Culture (30 min) ‚Äì A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.üîπ üöÄ Decision in <1 Week ‚Äì Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---üõ†Ô∏è It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? Let's discuss! üëáhashtag#DevOps hashtag#SRE hashtag#CloudEngineering hashtag#AIinTech hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Observability hashtag#Kubernetes hashtag#TechRecruiting hashtag#Infrastructure hashtag#CareerGrowth

üè¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ü§îIn the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stack‚Äîeveryone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Let‚Äôs break it down:üìå üöÄ Google‚Äôs Influence on Startups:üîπ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Google‚Äîeven if they don‚Äôt actually need that complexity.üîπ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Google‚Äôs work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.üîπ Hiring & Evaluation: Google‚Äôs System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.üîπ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesn‚Äôt guarantee success.üìå ‚öñÔ∏è When Does Copying Google Make Sense?‚úÖ If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.‚úÖ If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.‚úÖ If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.üìå ‚õî When Is It a Mistake?‚ùå If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.‚ùå If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.‚ùå If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because they‚Äôre "the industry standard."üîπ üí° The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didn‚Äôt come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processes‚Äîit came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?üí¨ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Share your thoughts! üëáhashtag#GoogleEffect hashtag#Startups hashtag#TechCulture hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Entrepreneurship üöÄ

Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noise‚Äîsaving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Here‚Äôs how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :‚Ä¢¬†Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.‚Ä¢¬†You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.‚Ä¢¬†Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrong‚Ä¢¬†~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. ‚Ä¢¬†Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.‚Ä¢¬†Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deploy‚Ä¢¬†Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. You can rollback patches as they are fully deployed builds.https://lnkd.in/gEA647dB

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. OPM Workforce Reshaping Handbookhttps://lnkd.in/g-6whAjN

DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

üîé Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles üöÄIn 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments üìù as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud roles‚Äîpositions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:üìå Does this reflect the real-world work environment?üìå Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?üìå Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?üîç Evidence & Trends:‚úÖ AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.‚úÖ Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.‚úÖ Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineering‚Äînot just coding fluency.‚ö†Ô∏è The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that don‚Äôt measure real-world capabilities.---üåç The Perfect Hiring Process ‚Äì If We Lived in a Perfect Worldüîπ üìû Intro Chat (30 min) ‚Äì A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just ‚Äútell me about yourself.‚Äùüîπ üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) ‚Äì A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.üîπ ‚ö° Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) ‚Äì A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!üîπ ü§ù Team Fit & Culture (30 min) ‚Äì A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.üîπ üöÄ Decision in <1 Week ‚Äì Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---üõ†Ô∏è It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? üè¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ü§îIn the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stack‚Äîeveryone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Let‚Äôs break it down:üìå üöÄ Google‚Äôs Influence on Startups:üîπ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Google‚Äîeven if they don‚Äôt actually need that complexity.üîπ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Google‚Äôs work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.üîπ Hiring & Evaluation: Google‚Äôs System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.üîπ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesn‚Äôt guarantee success.üìå ‚öñÔ∏è When Does Copying Google Make Sense?‚úÖ If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.‚úÖ If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.‚úÖ If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.üìå ‚õî When Is It a Mistake?‚ùå If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.‚ùå If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.‚ùå If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because they‚Äôre "the industry standard."üîπ üí° The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didn‚Äôt come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processes‚Äîit came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?üí¨ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Share your thoughts! üëáhashtag#GoogleEffect hashtag#Startups hashtag#TechCulture hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Entrepreneurship üöÄ

Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noise‚Äîsaving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Here‚Äôs how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :‚Ä¢¬†Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.‚Ä¢¬†You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.‚Ä¢¬†Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrong‚Ä¢¬†~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. ‚Ä¢¬†Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.‚Ä¢¬†Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deploy‚Ä¢¬†Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. You can rollback patches as they are fully deployed builds.https://lnkd.in/gEA647dB

The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.

üîé Rethinking Hiring for DevOps, SRE & Cloud Roles üöÄIn 2025, the tech landscape has evolved significantly. AI is no longer an option but a policy in many organizations, seamlessly integrated into the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) to enhance code quality, automate processes, and improve efficiency.Yet, many companies still insist on 7-day-long coding assessments üìù as part of the hiring process for DevOps, SRE, and Cloud roles‚Äîpositions where coding is rarely the primary responsibility. This raises critical questions:üìå Does this reflect the real-world work environment?üìå Why are we assessing senior engineers with tasks AI can complete in seconds?üìå Isn't experience, problem-solving, and system design more valuable than syntax-heavy coding?üîç Evidence & Trends:‚úÖ AI-Driven Development: According to a 2024 Stack Overflow report, 75%+ of engineers use AI tools like Copilot & ChatGPT to optimize coding tasks.‚úÖ Industry Shift: Companies like Google, Meta, and Amazon integrate AI-assisted development, focusing on problem-solving over raw coding skills.‚úÖ Hiring Reality: DevOps & SRE roles demand infrastructure expertise, automation, observability, and resilience engineering‚Äînot just coding fluency.‚ö†Ô∏è The Hiring Paradox:While AI is revolutionizing how engineers work, hiring processes remain outdated. Companies demand speed and innovation yet enforce rigid, manual, and time-consuming assessments that don‚Äôt measure real-world capabilities.---üåç The Perfect Hiring Process ‚Äì If We Lived in a Perfect Worldüîπ üìû Intro Chat (30 min) ‚Äì A real conversation with a hiring manager or lead engineer. Focus on expectations, team culture, and candidate experience, not just ‚Äútell me about yourself.‚Äùüîπ üõ†Ô∏è Hands-On Technical Discussion (1 hour) ‚Äì A collaborative session where candidates walk through their experience, explain past projects, system architecture, and troubleshooting strategies.üîπ ‚ö° Real-World Problem Solving (45 min) ‚Äì A live infrastructure challenge, like debugging a failing deployment, optimizing observability, or discussing scaling strategies. No unnecessary whiteboard coding!üîπ ü§ù Team Fit & Culture (30 min) ‚Äì A peer-to-peer conversation to ensure alignment with team values, communication, and collaboration style.üîπ üöÄ Decision in <1 Week ‚Äì Transparent feedback within days, not weeks. No unpaid take-home projects, just efficient, respectful hiring.---üõ†Ô∏è It's Time to Evolve Hiring!What are your thoughts? Have you faced outdated hiring practices? What does your ideal hiring process look like? üè¢ Why is Every Startup Trying to Be "Google"? ü§îIn the tech world, every startup dreams of becoming "the next Google." From internal culture to team structure and even the tech stack‚Äîeveryone is trying to replicate Google. But is this always a good thing? Let‚Äôs break it down:üìå üöÄ Google‚Äôs Influence on Startups:üîπ Engineering Architecture: Many startups adopt Microservices, Kubernetes, and Big Data Pipelines, just like Google‚Äîeven if they don‚Äôt actually need that complexity.üîπ Company Culture: From flat hierarchies to the famous "20% time for side projects," companies try to mimic Google‚Äôs work environment, often struggling due to different resources and scales.üîπ Hiring & Evaluation: Google‚Äôs System Design Interviews and Leetcode-style coding challenges have become industry standards, making it harder for new talent to break in.üîπ Innovation Obsession: Every startup wants to launch the next revolutionary product, but even Google has had major failures like Google+ and Stadia, proving that copying doesn‚Äôt guarantee success.üìå ‚öñÔ∏è When Does Copying Google Make Sense?‚úÖ If you're a large-scale company needing massive scalability.‚úÖ If you're working on high-traffic SaaS platforms that demand Google-like infrastructure.‚úÖ If you're adopting an innovation mindset, not just blindly following their playbook.üìå ‚õî When Is It a Mistake?‚ùå If you're a small startup that needs simplicity over complexity.‚ùå If you're using Google's practices without understanding why they work for them.‚ùå If you're adopting over-engineered solutions just because they‚Äôre "the industry standard."üîπ üí° The Bottom Line:Google is an incredible company, but its success didn‚Äôt come just from Kubernetes, remote work, or tough hiring processes‚Äîit came from vision, execution, and continuous iteration. If you're a startup, ask yourself: Do I need to be like Google, or do I need to be the best version of myself?üí¨ Do you think startups benefit from copying Google, or are they falling into an unnecessary complexity trap? Share your thoughts! üëáhashtag#GoogleEffect hashtag#Startups hashtag#TechCulture hashtag#DevOps hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#Entrepreneurship üöÄ

Too many resumes, not enough right-fit candidates? A trusted staffing partner helps cut through the noise‚Äîsaving time, connecting you to top talent, and streamlining hiring.  Here‚Äôs how:

Magento needs the confidence of "deploy-at-will".In my talk with customers, I have found that, when they think of Magento, they think of expensive downtimes during code deployments. Many are attracted to SaaS as they do not have to worry about code deploys. Magento merchants need to be given the confidence of "deploy-at-will". Friday evening or during a sales event. Recently David Lambauer posted about the scare of Friday deploys. His post and my response made me write down luroConnect's CI/CD and processes that have improved over the years and continue to improve with my discussions with developers and community.I had also conducted a workshop on this topic at hashtag#MM25IN and had received very good feedback.Highlights :‚Ä¢¬†Build without db strategy. I believe is the key! You get repeatable builds. It also helps Magento hosting become more compliant to the 12factor app.‚Ä¢¬†You can now use a build machine and not load the production system.‚Ä¢¬†Easy, one click rollbacks, just in case something went wrong‚Ä¢¬†~0 downtime deployments - facilitated by using a softlink to the web folder and relinking media and var. ‚Ä¢¬†Builds are done clean each time - starting with a git clone on an empty folder. No prior build artifacts hanging around. This reduces technical debt as find when we onboard customers - composer.lock not committed for example.‚Ä¢¬†Staging server with an ability to restore live db ensures builds are tested with as near production as possible, reducing possibility of a bad deploy‚Ä¢¬†Patch buids : Taking a few files live without the need for a full build. You can rollback patches as they are fully deployed builds.https://lnkd.in/gEA647dB

Employees at GSA received notification of initiation of RIF procedures this evening. OPM will also be asked to approve the offer of VERAs under the process.Federal News Network: https://lnkd.in/gBU6Tx3gTerms to READ MORE ABOUT:‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Area (p.29) -- the boundaries within which employees compete for retention under the RIF regulations. The competitive area includes all employees within the organizational unit(s) and geographical location(s) that are included in the competitive area definition. In any one RIF, an agency may not use one competitive area for the first round of competition, and a different competitive area for the second round of competition. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Competitive Level (p.34) -- groups of interchangeable positions. When the agency applies the four RIF retention factors (tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level, the competitive level becomes a retention register, which lists employees in the order of their relative retention standing. The terms ‚Äúcompetitive level‚Äù and ‚Äúretention register‚Äù are generally used in reference to a final retention register without regard to this distinction. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Register (p.38) -- applies the four retention factors required by law (i.e., tenure, veterans‚Äô preference, length of service, and performance ratings) to the competitive level. The retention register lists all competing employees in the order of their relative retention standing in a single competitive level. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Retention Standing (p.39) -- The four statutory retention factors are implemented in the following order on the retention register: 1.	 Tenure (p.39) -- implemented through three tenure groups; 2.	 Veterans‚Äô preference (p.42) -- three tenure subgroups on the retention register; 3.	 RIF Service Date (p.44) -- employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register; and4.	 Performance (p.45) -- additional service  added for retention to the employee‚Äôs service computation date on the retention register. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bump and Retreat Rights (p.58) -- three types of potential assignment rights to positions in different competitive levels through assignment by: ‚ÄúBumping" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee in a lower retention tenure group, or in a lower subgroup within the same tenure group‚ÄúRetreating" -- assignment to a position in a different competitive level held by another employee with less service in the same retention subgroup.Offers of vacant positions, which are based on the same retention standing procedures that apply to an employee‚Äôs bump and retreat rights. OPM Workforce Reshaping Handbookhttps://lnkd.in/g-6whAjN

DevOps Engineer != SRE Engineer.Let's clarify the differences once and for all.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on system reliability metrics, DevOps engineers optimize deployment pipelines.‚Ü≥ while SREs live and die by SLOs/SLIs, DevOps engineers obsess over CI/CD success rates.‚Ü≥ while SREs are deep in incident management, DevOps engineers are knee-deep in automation scripts.‚Ü≥ while SREs need to master monitoring at scale, DevOps engineers need to master infrastructure as code.‚Ü≥ while SREs focus on reducing toil, DevOps engineers focus on reducing deployment friction.‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢Distinctions in initial qualifications for DevOps and SRE career paths ~- DevOps welcomes beginners who understand the basics of automation and collaboration. - SRE positions usually demand seasoned engineers who've already dealt with complex system reliability challenges.
